@Blockstream @AvantiBT @adam3us @GovernorGordon 9/ In a #bailment, the concept is your asset remains legally yours even if you give temporary possession of it to a service provider for safekeeping (so if your service provider goes bust while holding your asset in its custody you get it back w/o waiting thru messy bankruptcy).

@Blockstream @AvantiBT @adam3us @GovernorGordon 8/ Remember, #Wyoming law is uniquely consumer friendly bc it enables custody via #bailment (same legal treatment as valet parking or coat check‚Äîu give possession of your property to a service provider, but not legal title, & the service provider can‚Äôt use it for its own benefit)

9/ Net-net, this is a positive proposal. Lots more clarification needed to make it workable in practice, but it certainly has started the discussion! Well done @HesterPeirce! ü§†

8/...#utilitytoken law, it could work‚Äîbut more states would need to adopt that (it‚Äôs just the Rocky Mtn states that have thus far). I suspect many more states would welcome the ability to clarify this & would adopt this approach if the SEC proposal would fit well with state laws.

7/ Some states may object to expansion of the SEC‚Äôs jurisdiction beyond securities (as they did with the OCC‚Äôs attempted expansion of jurisdiction with its fintech charter, which the states have pretty much succeeded in blocking via the courts). If other states adopt #Wyoming‚Äôs..

6/...jurisdiction over property. So, for the proposal to work, the SEC would need to cooperate with the states. This matters a lot, bc property & securities are treated differently under commercial law (diff negotiability, diff ways of perfecting security interest, etc).

5/ So this proposal moves the ball but there‚Äôs still a big catch-22 preventing the security token industry from flourishing in the US. BUT, on the other hand, if the tokens aren‚Äôt presumed securities during the 3-yr grace period, then they‚Äôre property. States, not the SEC, have..

4/ Per the joint SEC/Finra guidance last summer (footnote 13), banks have a safe harbor for good control location‚Äîbut since the FDIC isn‚Äôt allowing US banks to custody digital assets as of now, no custodian can provide that safe harbor (until a #Wyoming SPDI gets chartered!).

3/ The custody question is YUGE. If they‚Äôre presumed securities, then the Custody Rule & Customer Protection Rule probably apply. This means custodians must provide ‚Äúgood control location‚Äù (among other obligations), but there‚Äôs zero clarity on what that means for security tokens.

2/ If yes, then the proposal opens at least 2 cans of worms‚Äîthe custody question + creates probs for issuers outside the US (where many countries recognize that tokens aren‚Äôt necessarily securities but if the US thinks they‚Äôre securities then other countries may follow)...

1/THINKING MORE abt @HesterPeirce‚Äôs proposal for a token safe harbor, which really does advance the ball re US SEC issues. As per my pvs tweets, there are issues that still need to be addressed‚Äîbasic one is whether the tokens are presumed securities during the safe harbor or not.

8/ ...It was a human tragedy of epic proportions, but until past few years I didn't realize how thoroughly it crippled the Soviet economy too. (Side note--I wrote abt why Russia's economy has historically been so counter-cyclical to that of the West here:) https://t.co/KpMsLf5vt9

7/ ...For example, Soviet Russia's economy was obviously unstable for decades (obvious to those who studied it), before the Chernobyl disaster finally pushed it over the edge--tho even that took time to play out. Gorbachev rightly agreed Chernobyl was the precipitating event.

6/ ...So, what causes economies to fail? It's always a confluence but there's usually a precipitating event that triggers dominoes to fall--dominoes that were obviously unstable (sometimes for years or decades), but obvious only to those who got curious & studied them...

5/ ...So, is #coronavirus the trigger that pricks the world's credit bubble? It's FAR TOO EARLY to say & depends on how the virus evolves. But Doug's piece got me thinking about connections. Airplane crashes are never caused by just one event--always a confluence of several...

4/ ...I spent much of my career in&around the life insurance/pension biz, so am v familiar w/ the epic 1918 Spanish flu pandemic's actuarial characteristics. #coronavirus is FAR FAR from that, for now (Spanish flu esp hit kids & elderly, but adults generally had better immunity).

3/ ...Because no event has yet triggered a reckoning that reveals the insolvency. (Again, banks can stay in biz for a long time after they're insolvent.) Markets clearly worry that #coronavirus might be such a trigger--Doug details the huge mkt moves this week in reaction to it.

2/ ...entire economies can stay afloat long after their balance sheets are used up too, as long as credit keeps flowing. Credit capacity for most of the developed world is mostly used up (it's why interest rates are negative in many places), but they're still afloat. Why?

1/ GREAT NUGGETS of wisdom from Doug Noland's post...gets me thinking on Saturdays‚òïÔ∏è. FIRST, is #coronavirus just usual media fearmongering or a tragedy that could prick the huge credit bubble? Just\nas banks can stay liquid LONG after they're insolvent... https://t.co/N0eRT7Cqb4

@garypalmerjr Yep. Best example of a #bailment is valet parking. You give up possession but not title/control of your car. When you ask for it back they must deliver it‚Äî&, CRITICALLY, if the garage goes bust w/ your car parked in it you don‚Äôt need to petition a bankruptcy judge to get it back!
RT @garypalmerjr: Word of the year: #Bailment | #Bitcoin #Blockchain https://t.co/ZISo0YtVsu

@mikebelshe @CarstenBKK @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo This is why a state-chartered bank is so powerful‚Äîa #Wyoming SPDI has trust powers just like a trust company does, but it‚Äôs ALSO a bank‚Äîwhich brings a host of addl advantages. One adv is portability into 42 states. Last I recall only about 10 states have trust company reciprocity

@_drgo @mikebelshe @CarstenBKK @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo Yep‚Äîyou nailed it Dr Goss. Bailment in a directly-owned asset has superior rights to either (1) bailment in an indirectly owned asset or (2) simple contractual guarantee. Bailment keeps assets out of bankruptcy estate, while the others likely do not

@LukeYoungblood @mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo Hi‚Äîthat‚Äôs not the issue (of course a trust company can contract for depositors to control their assets). The issue is what happens if the trust company goes bust‚Äîthe best legal protection for the investor is bailment in a directly owned asset, & that‚Äôs only available in #Wyoming

@mikebelshe @CarstenBKK @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo In a bankruptcy, judges look to the legal definition of an asset under STATE law. #SouthDakota has 791 words of #blockchain laws on its books (just a definition of blockchain). #Wyoming has 42,691 words‚Äî54x more detail. Legal certainty in bankruptcy is a big issue for fiduciaries

@mikebelshe @CarstenBKK @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo Mike‚Äîmay I suggest your attorney analyze this for you? State bank charters are much more portable than trust company charters bc 42 states recognize other states‚Äô state-chartered banks. A federal charter wouldn‚Äôt make a difference on this pt bc #bailment is state law, not federal

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo No. Only in #Wyoming are #crypto depositors protected by #bailment law. @mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 7/ ...We think #Wyoming‚Äôs special-purpose depository charter is portable into 42 states (+ likely to be refined to make it more attractive in next legislative session). @mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 6/ And you have another incentive‚Äî#Wyoming digital asset custodians are banks, not trust cos. Banks are exempt from most state money transmission laws + banks have special status under the federal Exchange Act of 1933 (15 U.S.C. 78c(a)(6) does NOT include a trust company)...

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 5/ ...against that bad outcome. I agree w/ the decision Bitgo & others made to set up trust cos initially, since #Wyoming‚Äôs laws didn‚Äôt exist yet‚Äîbut we‚Äôd love to have you convert into #Wyoming (& think you‚Äôll decide to anyway over time bc mkt is likely to go in that direction).

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 4/ ...judge/regulator is likely to follow the most applicable precedent‚ÄîUCC Article 8 (which treats customer assets as fungible, would break the customer‚Äôs contractual right of ownership in bankruptcy & socialize the loss to customers pro rata). Again, only #Wyoming protects...

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 3/ ...so the outcome is unpredictable. The first question a fiduciary will ask is ‚Äúwhat happens if my custodian goes bust?‚Äù bc they have fiduciary liability‚Äî& there‚Äôs only one state whose laws can answer that question at all (#Wyoming). In the absence of such legal clarity, the..

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 2/ ..but in #Wyoming the law makes it clear that a bankruptcy judge cannot grab customer assets to satisfy a shortfall, using customer assets to socialize losses. All other states‚Äô laws are silent on this issue, which means bankruptcy judges (& state regulators) have no roadmap..

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo 1/ There‚Äôs a huge difference & I‚Äôm glad we‚Äôre discussing it‚Äîsounds like Bitgo offers a CONTRACTUAL right of ownership, but #Wyoming law guarantees customers a direct PROPERTY right, which is superior. Huge difference in a bankruptcy, where bankruptcy judge can break contracts...

@mikebelshe @Melt_Dem @fintechfrank @jillruthcarlson @BitGo No, it is unique to Wyoming law. No other state offers this legal regime‚Äîit‚Äôs called a bailment. It is the strongest legal protection, where legally the custodian is merely a directed trustee. That doesn‚Äôt exist in any other US jurisdiction

7/ So...#NewYork did good investigative work here but needs to be called to task on why the double standard, and why the "gotcha" approach? Why not do the same to #WallSt firms when they play similar shell games???

6/ Yeah, that Merrill stuff was pretty bad, and it paid a $415mm fine to the SEC in 2016. But the SEC handled it in a manner that didn't spark sudden panic & customer withdrawals from Merrill. But today, #NewYork went w/ the "gotcha" approach & pockets of panic seem to be ensuing

5/ But there's MORE! Merrill held $58bn/day (!!!) of customer securities in an account subject to its creditor lien. Per the SEC, "Had Merrill Lynch collapsed at any point, customers would have been exposed to significant risk & uncertainty of getting back their own securities."

4/ WAIT -- PLEASE STOP AND READ THAT AGAIN üëÜ. It's really important. So...Merrill Lynch commingled customer funds, used them to cover its own obligations, & had it failed its customers would have been exposed to a "massive shortfall in the reserve account." Where was the NY AG??

3/ "The maneuver freed up billions of dollars per week from 2009-12 that Merrill Lynch used to finance its own trading activities.  Had Merrill Lynch failed in the midst of these trades, the firm‚Äôs customers would have been exposed to a massive shortfall in the reserve account."
